text: - Hi, I'm Ayesha Borker,

a Senior Solution Architect
for Amazon Connect.

Amazon Connect is an omnichannel
cloud-based contact center

that helps you provide
superior customer service
at a lower cost.

In this video, we'll
explore Amazon Connect Tasks

and how it can help improve
your agent productivity
as well as car customer experience.
In many contact centers,

agents spent a significant
time working on activities

outside of the typical
voice or chat channel.

These activities could include
working on a customer case,
updating a CRM, managing tickets,
completing a backend workflow,
or even following up with a customer.

Tracking the time spent on
these activities manually
can be error-prone, as well as difficult,

as they are spread
across disparate systems.

Tasks is a feature of Amazon
Connect that solves for this
by making it simple to route, prioritize,
and keep track of the activities

or assignments your contact
center agents are working on.

It allows your agents to
complete these activities
from the same agent's softphone interface
that they already use for the voice
and chat channels within Amazon Connect,

providing them with a seamless
and unified experience.

It also provides a unified
reporting dashboard

for your supervisor,
making it easy for them
to track agent productivity metrics
from a single source of truth.

Let us now see how this
looks like in action,
beginning with the agent experience.
On the left side of the screen,

you can see that I have logged
into the customer portal
for a ride service company
as a fictitious customer named Brienne.
On the right side, I have logged

into the Amazon Connect
Contact Control Panel,
or the CCP, as an agent.
On the top right of the CCP,

the small briefcase icon
allows agents to receive tasks

on their softphones based on
their routing configurations.
I will now initiate a chat interaction
as the customer Brienne.

I am presented with a
personalized self-service bot,

and I simply want to report
the loss of my wallet.
I answer a series of questions,

and I request a follow up
on my case via an email.
(light music)

Based on the information
captured on the bot,

a task is created and
assigned to our agent Ayesha.
On accepting the task,
I have the entire context on the case

and the follow up
preference of the customer,
which is email.

The timer here keeps a
track of how much time
I am spending on this task as an agent.

Now, let's say I worked
with my internal team
and I resolved this issue.
I can also schedule another automated task
to follow up with this customer

on their preferred
channel, which is email.

To do this, let's click
on the briefcase icon
on the bottom left this time.
I can enter the required details.
(light music)
You can add additional links
that you need to share with the customer
and assign this to a quick connect.

This quick connect will
trigger an automated workflow

that follows up with
the customer over email.
You can also schedule a date and time
for this follow up, if you prefer,

but for now, we will leave
this blank and create a task.
If I quickly check my inbox,
I now have received a follow-up email
with the details of my lost item.
This follow could have been an SMS

or even a phone call
based on your use case.

In this example, not only did
we see how cases can be routed
to an agent using Tasks

but also how we can eliminate
repetitive manual workflows
such as sending an email or an SMS
by automating them using Tasks.
This automation concept could be extended
to numerous other use cases,
such as updating a CRM post call,
initiating a back office workflow
for another team to work on,
or simply scheduling a follow-up call
with a customer at a later date.
Let's now explore the supervisor
or the administrator experience.

Here, I have logged into
my Amazon Connect Dashboard
as an administrator.

I have the capability
to configure an agent
to receive tasks under Routing profiles.

In this sample routing
profile, I can enable Tasks

and configure a maximum of 10
simultaneous tasks per agent.
I can add my queues below

and pick and choose the channel
assigned to these queues.

I can also determine the priority
of these queues if needed.

Once done, you can assign
this profile to your agents

who will start receiving
tasks accordingly.

As you can see, the supervisor
dashboard is unified
and seamless for all channels.

Additionally, all of your
contact center metrics for Tasks
are available for supervisor
in a unified reporting dashboard.
Amazon Connect provides out-of-the-box,

real-time and historical
metrics for tasks.
Currently, I have navigated to one

of the available real-time
reports filtered by agents.

I have a unified view of the
channels my agents are handling
that includes tasks.

I can see how many tasks
are available in queue,
how many are active,

and the agent availability,
as well amongst other metrics.

This helps in seamlessly
integrating external activities
within your contact center metrics

and getting a holistic view
of your agent productivity

across all engagements
that they work in a day.
We have a create task block,
using which you can create a task easily

from within an Amazon Connect
contact flow experience.

We also have APIs which
makes the solution open

and provides you the
flexibility to innovate.

And finally, Tasks provides
pre-built connectors
with Salesforce and Zendesk

that you can integrate with
a click of few buttons.
You can enable these connectors
from the AWS Management Console
by navigating to your instance settings.

By clicking on Tasks, you
can add an application.

You can choose between
Salesforce and Zendesk
by clicking on the button.
I'm gonna select Salesforce.

You can then fill out
your instance details
and click on Establish a connection.

Once this is done, you're
all set up and ready to go.
You can also define rules to trigger tasks
such as when a new case

for a high priority
customer case is created
and then route that to agents.

This brings us to the
end of our demonstration.
I hope you enjoyed this video.
To learn more about Amazon Connect Tasks,
visit aws.com/connect.
